Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Story:
I watched my stepbrother lace up his sneakers, his skateboard already perched at the top of the steep, cracked ramp behind our house. He grinned at me, excitement in his eyes, but all I could see was the jagged concrete and the memory of his last fall. As his step-sibling, I felt the weight of responsibility—Mom always said we had to look out for each other, and I knew she trusted me to keep him safe. I wanted to tell him to wait, to practice somewhere safer, but I also didn’t want to be the nagging sister who ruined his fun.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my boyfriend, asking which night I wanted to go out this week. He’d been hinting that we needed more time together, just us, and I missed him too. But if I left now, I’d be abandoning my stepbrother right when he might need me most. My heart twisted as I tried to balance the pull of both roles—caring for my family and nurturing my relationship—knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
